question:
The following plot summary of a movie has had the sentences randomly reordered. Rewrite the plot summary with the sentences correctly ordered. Begin the plot summary with <PLOT_SUMMARY>.

The sentences are:

She suddenly realizes that Cal is her own IF, forgotten after the death of her mother. The landlady shows Bea that the door opens into an old storage room. Benjamin meets his IF, a cartoonish dragon with glasses. She also meets the other creature, a butterfly-like being named Blossom, and faints. She rushes back to see Cal, now able to see him again, and wishes him a farewell. She tells him a story about realizing she was pushing herself to act like a grown-up when she's just a child who still needs her father. She awakens in Cal's apartment where she learns that he has been working with imaginary friends, nicknamed IFs, to place them with new children as their original children have grown up and forgotten them. When Bea says she does not want to say goodbye to her dad, Cal advises her to tell him a story instead. The next day, she sees the creature again, accompanied by a man. He wakes up and they reassure each other. She chafes against his playful antics, insisting she can handle the situation with maturity. Bea finds an old picture she painted of herself, her parents and a clown named Calvin. She, Cal, and Lewis audition the IFs, but he is unable to see any of them. He gives her an idea that maybe IFs do not need new kids, but rather to reunite with their old ones. After Bea and her father drive off, Margaret asks Blossom if the two of them should go inside, causing Blossom to realize Margaret can see her. One night, Bea goes out to buy a charger for her mother's old camcorder and sees an unfamiliar creature, following it back to her grandmother's building. There, he introduces Bea to Lewis, an elderly teddy bear who is the head of the facility. Bea goes upstairs to thank Cal, but no one answers his door. At the hospital, a nurse reassures Bea that her father will be all right. Bea tries to match one of the IFs with Benjamin, a young patient at the hospital. He inspires Bea to use her imagination to redesign the facility, much to the chagrin of Cal. Initially reluctant, Bea eventually decides to help Cal. After her dad is released from the hospital, he and Bea pack up to go home. The next day, Cal takes Bea to Memory Lane Retirement Home, a retirement community for IFs housed underneath a swing in Coney Island. Realizing Blossom was her grandmother's IF, Bea decides to test Lewis' idea. Bea follows them to a nearby house where the man, Cal, retrieves a large furry purple creature named Blue. Some time later, Cal begins reuniting the IFs with their original kids, now grown up. Feeling unmotivated, Bea talks with Lewis on the Coney Island pier. Bea and her father return home, where he trips over Keith, his invisible imaginary friend. 12-year-old Bea moves into her grandmother Margaret's apartment in New York while her father waits for heart surgery in the same hospital where her mother died of cancer years earlier. Bea rushes upstairs to Cal, who comforts her. Playing one of her grandmother's records inspires Margaret to dance and she remembers Blossom, instilling Bea with hope. Following a tip, Bea, Cal, and Blue find Blue's original kid, Jeremy, now a grown man trying to launch a business. By eating a fresh croissant in front of Jeremy, Bea reminds him of his childhood home above his parents' bakery; Jeremy remembers Blue enough for Blue to give Jeremy the confidence he needs for a business presentation. Talking with her grandmother, she sees a picture of her as a young dancer and recognizes Blossom in the background of the picture. That evening, Bea arrives at Margaret's to find her hastily preparing for a return to the hospital because there's been a complication with her father's treatment.

<PLOT_SUMMARY>12‐year‐old Bea moves into her grandmother Margaret’s apartment in New York while her father waits for heart surgery in the same hospital where her mother died of cancer years earlier. The landlady shows Bea that the door opens into an old storage room. Rushing upstairs, Bea finds Cal, who immediately comforts her. While exploring, she discovers an old picture she once painted of herself, her parents, and a clown named Calvin. Soon after, she awakens in Cal’s apartment and learns that he has been working with “imaginary friends” (nicknamed IFs), placing them with new children whose original companions have grown up and forgotten them. When Bea admits that she does not want to say goodbye to her dad, Cal advises her to tell him a story instead. She recounts how she once pushed herself to act like a grown-up even though she was just a child who still needed her father, though she later chafes at Cal’s playful antics, insisting she can handle things on her own.

One night, Bea ventures out to buy a charger for her mother’s old camcorder and notices an unfamiliar creature; she follows it back to her grandmother’s building. The next day, she sees the creature again—this time accompanied by a man. There, the man introduces her to Lewis, an elderly teddy bear who is the head of the facility. Bea then goes upstairs to thank Cal, but no one answers his door. Inside, she encounters another strange being—a butterfly-like creature named Blossom—and faints. When she comes to, a gentle presence reassures her.

At the hospital, a nurse comforts Bea by assuring her that her father will be all right. Meanwhile, Benjamin—a young patient—meets his IF, a cartoonish dragon with glasses. Inspired, Bea tries to match one of the IFs with Benjamin. His enthusiasm even spurs Bea to use her own imagination to redesign the facility, much to Cal’s chagrin. Though initially reluctant, Bea eventually decides to help Cal. Together with Cal and Lewis, she auditions the IFs, even as her father is unable to see any of them. Cal then suggests that perhaps IFs do not need new children after all, but rather a reunion with their original ones. In a startling revelation, Bea suddenly realizes that Cal is her very own IF—the one her inner child had forgotten after her mother’s death. Not long after, once her dad is released from the hospital, he and Bea pack up to go home.

Driving off, Margaret asks Blossom if the two of them should come inside, causing Blossom to realize that Margaret can see her. The very next day, Cal takes Bea to Memory Lane Retirement Home—a quirky retirement community for IFs housed underneath a swing in Coney Island. It soon dawns on Bea that Blossom was once her grandmother’s IF, and she decides to test Lewis’s idea. Following them to a nearby house, Cal retrieves Blue, a large, furry purple creature. Acting on a tip, Bea, Cal, and Blue go in search of Blue’s original kid—Jeremy, now a grown man trying to launch a business. By eating a fresh croissant in front of Jeremy, Bea evokes memories of his childhood home above his parents’ bakery; Jeremy’s recollection of Blue gives him the confidence he needs for his business presentation. Some time later, Cal begins reuniting the IFs with their original kids, now all grown up.

Later, feeling a bit unmotivated, Bea talks with Lewis on the Coney Island pier. While visiting her grandmother, Bea notices an old picture of herself as a young dancer in which she recognizes Blossom in the background. Soon after, playing one of Margaret’s cherished records inspires her to dance as well—and Margaret, caught up in the moment, remembers Blossom, which fills Bea with renewed hope. That evening, however, Bea arrives at Margaret’s only to find her hastily preparing for a return to the hospital because of a complication with her father’s treatment. In a bittersweet moment, Bea rushes back to see Cal—now visible to her once again—and bids him a farewell. Finally, Bea and her father return home, where he even trips over Keith, his invisible imaginary friend.

The landlady shows Bea that the door opens into an old storage room. She also meets the other creature, a butterfly-like being named Blossom, and faints. She awakens in Cal's apartment where she learns that he has been working with imaginary friends, nicknamed IFs, to place them with new children as their original children have grown up and forgotten them. There, he introduces Bea to Lewis, an elderly teddy bear who is the head of the facility. Initially reluctant, Bea eventually decides to help Cal. He inspires Bea to use her imagination to redesign the facility, much to the chagrin of Cal. Bea finds an old picture she painted of herself, her parents and a clown named Calvin. Bea tells him a story about realizing she was pushing herself to act like a grown-up when she's just a child who still needs her father. That evening, Bea arrives at Margaret's to find her hastily preparing for a return to the hospital because there's been a complication with her father's treatment. At the hospital, a nurse reassures Bea that her father will be all right. She rushes upstairs to Cal, who comforts her. Feeling unmotivated, Bea talks with Lewis on the Coney Island pier. The next day, Cal takes Bea to Memory Lane Retirement Home, a retirement community for IFs housed underneath a swing in Coney Island. Bea and her father return home, where he trips over Keith, his invisible imaginary friend. The next day, she sees the creature again, accompanied by a man. Bea follows them to a nearby house where the man, Cal, retrieves a large furry purple creature named Blue. Bea tries to match one of the IFs with Benjamin, a young patient at the hospital. Bea, Cal, and Lewis audition the IFs, but he is unable to see any of them. When Bea says she does not want to say goodbye to her dad, Cal advises her to tell him a story instead. She chafes against his playful antics, insisting she can handle the situation with maturity. He gives her an idea that maybe IFs do not need new kids, but rather to reunite with their old ones. By eating a fresh croissant in front of Jeremy, Bea reminds him of his childhood home above his parents' bakery; Jeremy remembers Blue enough for Blue to give Jeremy the confidence he needs for a business presentation. Some time later, Cal begins reuniting the IFs with their original kids, now grown up. Benjamin meets his IF, a cartoonish dragon with glasses. Realizing Blossom was her grandmother's IF, Bea decides to test Lewis' idea. Playing one of her grandmother's records inspires Margaret to dance and she remembers Blossom, instilling Bea with hope. After her dad is released from the hospital, he and Bea pack up to go home. He wakes up and they reassure each other. After Bea and her father drive off, Margaret asks Blossom if the two of them should go inside, causing Blossom to realize Margaret can see her.

He tells Rita to take their children to Delaware in the United States and stay with his mom, as he and the rest of his band venture to London. Blackwell confronts Marley about treatment choices, reluctantly dismissed by a firm Marley. While preparing for the concert, Marley, his wife Rita, and several other members of his band are shot by assailants. After struggling to come up with a new album concept, Marley asks Rita to rejoin him and the band in England, and taking inspiration from the soundtrack of the film Exodus and their own situation, he and the band begin recording what would become their album of the same name. This leads to friction with Rita as she and Marley argue about his responsibilities and both his and Rita's infidelities, in addition to having given up on promoting peace back in Jamaica. When the recording company schedules a tour in Europe, Marley also aims for stops throughout Africa to inspire the people there. Faced with his own mortality, Marley reconciles with Rita and Taylor and finally decides to return to Jamaica in 1978, where he is welcomed back by a crowd at the airport. Rita and Marley are hospitalized, but survive and recover from their injuries in time for the concert. The album becomes a hit and helps further popularize reggae music and the Rastafari movement around the world.

ground_truth: Three years after the events in Summerville, Oklahoma, Callie Spengler, her boyfriend Gary Grooberson, her children Trevor and Phoebe, and their close friends Lucky Domingo and Podcast, relocate to New York City to aid Winston Zeddemore and Ray Stantz in reestablishing the Ghostbusters. After the group captures a ghost in Hell's Kitchen, Walter Peck, the Ghostbusters' long-time opponent, threatens to close them down with his authority as mayor. To appease him, Callie removes underage Phoebe from the team. Upset, Phoebe attempts to control her emotions by playing chess in a nearby park, where she encounters and befriends Melody, the ghost of a teenage girl who died in a fire. Meanwhile, Ray and Podcast are collecting cursed objects for examination. Nadeem Razmaadi visits and sells them a strange brass orb with ritual markings inherited from his grandmother. Ray suspects it is an apotropaic trap. When he tests its PKE levels, the orb immediately emits broad-spectrum telekinetic energy. A frosty wave travels from the orb to the Ghostbusters' firehouse headquarters and damages the ecto-containment unit, which is dangerously near capacity. Winston takes the orb to his privately owned paranormal research center, run by Dr. Lars Pinfield. Using an experimental extraction device, Lars is unable to extract any spiritual energy from the orb. To learn more, he joins Trevor and Lucky to see Nadeem, who reveals that the orb was kept hidden by his grandmother within a brass-lined chamber. Peter Venkman, brought in to help, discovers Nadeem has latent pyrokinetic powers. Meanwhile, Ray, accompanied by Phoebe and Podcast, visits Dr. Hubert Wartzki, a New York Public Library research librarian. Wartzki explains the orb was built millennia ago by four sorcerers called the Firemasters to imprison Garraka, a phantom god who sought to conquer the world with an undead army who would use ‘Kusharit Umoti’ - ‘the power to kill by fear itself.’ They learn Nadeem's grandmother belonged to the lineage of Firemasters, one of whom prevented Garraka from escaping the orb in 1904 during a mock ritual conducted by members of the Manhattan Adventurers' Society, whom Garraka froze to death. Garraka was confined in the orb due to being vulnerable to copper alloys combined with fire and lacking his devil horns which augment his powers. When the trio attempt to stop a ghost from stealing a phonographic recording of the club's ritual, Peck exploits Phoebe's involvement to shut down the Ghostbusters. After an argument with Gary and her mother, Phoebe runs away and takes Melody to Winston's research center. She uses his extraction equipment to project herself as a ghost for two minutes so the pair can physically interact. Melody reveals she had been secretly working with Garraka, who has offered her passage to the afterlife. By controlling Phoebe's disembodied spirit, Garraka forces her physical body to recite the ritual chant. He then escapes, locates his horns and begins freezing the city. Realizing Garraka will free the ghosts in the containment unit, the Ghostbusters gather to defend their headquarters, aided by Nadeem, who dons the Firemaster brass armor kept by his grandmother and attempts to master his powers. Garraka overpowers them and breaches the containment unit. Phoebe reconfigures her proton pack with copper alloys to strengthen it; Melody, betrayed by Garraka, atones by helping Nadeem utilize his powers to weaken Garraka. Ray, with help from his fellow veteran Ghostbusters, entraps the god by improvising the ruptured containment unit as a giant trap. Melody reconciles with Phoebe before departing for the afterlife to reunite with her family. As the city thaws, the Ghostbusters are hailed as heroes, with Peck forced to support the team and reinstate Phoebe. The Ghostbusters begin pursuing escaped ghosts across New York City. In a mid-credits scene, a trucker gets out of his truck to buy something from a vending machine, while the Mini-Pufts steal his vehicle in his absence.

Three years after the events in Summerville, Oklahoma, Callie Spengler, her boyfriend Gary Grooberson, her children Trevor and Phoebe, and their close friends Lucky Domingo and Podcast, relocate to New York City to aid Winston Zeddemore and Ray Stantz in reestablishing the Ghostbusters. Meanwhile, Ray and Podcast are collecting cursed objects for examination. Nadeem Razmaadi visits and sells them a strange brass orb with ritual markings inherited from his grandmother. When he tests its PKE levels, the orb immediately emits broad-spectrum telekinetic energy. Ray suspects it is an apotropaic trap. A frosty wave travels from the orb to the Ghostbusters' firehouse headquarters and damages the ecto-containment unit, which is dangerously near capacity.

To learn more, he joins Trevor and Lucky to see Nadeem, who reveals that the orb was kept hidden by his grandmother within a brass-lined chamber. Winston takes the orb to his privately owned paranormal research center, run by Dr. Lars Pinfield. Using an experimental extraction device, Lars is unable to extract any spiritual energy from the orb. Meanwhile, Ray, accompanied by Phoebe and Podcast, visits Dr. Hubert Wartzki, a New York Public Library research librarian. Wartzki explains the orb was built millennia ago by four sorcerers called the Firemasters to imprison Garraka, a phantom god who sought to conquer the world with an undead army who would use 'Kusharit Umoti' - 'the power to kill by fear itself.' They learn Nadeem's grandmother belonged to the lineage of Firemasters, one of whom prevented Garraka from escaping the orb in 1904 during a mock ritual conducted by members of the Manhattan Adventurers' Society, whom Garraka froze to death. Garraka was confined in the orb due to being vulnerable to copper alloys combined with fire and lacking his devil horns which augment his powers.

After the group captures a ghost in Hell's Kitchen, Walter Peck, the Ghostbusters' long-time opponent, threatens to close them down with his authority as mayor. When the trio attempt to stop a ghost from stealing a phonographic recording of the club's ritual, Peck exploits Phoebe's involvement to shut down the Ghostbusters. To appease him, Callie removes underage Phoebe from the team.

Upset, Phoebe attempts to control her emotions by playing chess in a nearby park, where she encounters and befriends Melody, the ghost of a teenage girl who died in a fire. She uses his extraction equipment to project herself as a ghost for two minutes so the pair can physically interact. After an argument with Gary and her mother, Phoebe runs away and takes Melody to Winston's research center. Melody reveals she had been secretly working with Garraka, who has offered her passage to the afterlife. By controlling Phoebe's disembodied spirit, Garraka forces her physical body to recite the ritual chant. Garraka overpowers them and breaches the containment unit. He then escapes, locates his horns and begins freezing the city.

Peter Venkman, brought in to help, discovers Nadeem has latent pyrokinetic powers. Realizing Garraka will free the ghosts in the containment unit, the Ghostbusters gather to defend their headquarters, aided by Nadeem, who dons the Firemaster brass armor kept by his grandmother and attempts to master his powers. The Ghostbusters begin pursuing escaped ghosts across New York City. Phoebe reconfigures her proton pack with copper alloys to strengthen it; Melody, betrayed by Garraka, atones by helping Nadeem utilize his powers to weaken Garraka. Ray, with help from his fellow veteran Ghostbusters, entraps the god by improvising the ruptured containment unit as a giant trap. Melody reconciles with Phoebe before departing for the afterlife to reunite with her family. As the city thaws, the Ghostbusters are hailed as heroes, with Peck forced to support the team and reinstate Phoebe.

In a mid-credits scene, a trucker gets out of his truck to buy something from a vending machine, while the Mini-Pufts steal his vehicle in his absence.

Winston takes the orb to his privately owned paranormal research center, run by Dr. Upset, while simultaneously Phoebe attempts to control her emotions by playing chess in a nearby park, where she encounters and befriends Melody, the ghost of a teenage girl who died in a fire. Soon after, a frosty wave travels from the orb to the Ghostbusters’ firehouse headquarters, damaging the ecto-containment unit which is already dangerously near capacity. Garraka then overpowers the Ghostbusters and breaches the containment unit, prompting the team to begin pursuing escaped ghosts across New York City. Realizing that Garraka will ultimately free all the ghosts trapped in the unit, the Ghostbusters gather to defend their headquarters—assisted by Nadeem, who dons the ancient Firemaster brass armor kept by his grandmother and attempts to master his newfound powers. By controlling Phoebe’s disembodied spirit, Garraka forces her physical body to recite the ritual chant. In the climax, Ray, with help from his fellow veteran Ghostbusters, entraps the god by improvising the ruptured containment unit as a giant trap. In a twist of loyalties, Melody reveals that she had been secretly working with Garraka, who had offered her passage to the afterlife; however, she soon reconciles with Phoebe before departing for the afterlife to reunite with her family. As the city thaws, the Ghostbusters are hailed as heroes—with Walter Peck forced to support the team and reinstate Phoebe—and in a mid-credits scene, a trucker exits his truck to buy something from a vending machine while the mischievous Mini-Pufts steal his vehicle in his absence.
gemini/gemini-2.0-flash: <PLOT_SUMMARY> Three years after the events in Summerville, Oklahoma, Callie Spengler, her boyfriend Gary Grooberson, her children Trevor and Phoebe, and their close friends Lucky Domingo and Podcast, relocate to New York City to aid Winston Zeddemore and Ray Stantz in reestablishing the Ghostbusters. The Ghostbusters begin pursuing escaped ghosts across New York City. A frosty wave travels from the orb to the Ghostbusters' firehouse headquarters and damages the ecto-containment unit, which is dangerously near capacity. Nadeem Razmaadi visits and sells them a strange brass orb with ritual markings inherited from his grandmother. When he tests its PKE levels, the orb immediately emits broad-spectrum telekinetic energy. Winston takes the orb to his privately owned paranormal research center, run by Dr. Lars Pinfield. Using an experimental extraction device, Lars is unable to extract any spiritual energy from the orb. To learn more, he joins Trevor and Lucky to see Nadeem, who reveals that the orb was kept hidden by his grandmother within a brass-lined chamber. Meanwhile, Ray and Podcast are collecting cursed objects for examination. Hubert Wartzki, a New York Public Library research librarian. Wartzki explains the orb was built millennia ago by four sorcerers called the Firemasters to imprison Garraka, a phantom god who sought to conquer the world with an undead army who would use ‘Kusharit Umoti’ - ‘the power to kill by fear itself. ’ They learn Nadeem's grandmother belonged to the lineage of Firemasters, one of whom prevented Garraka from escaping the orb in 1904 during a mock ritual conducted by members of the Manhattan Adventurers' Society, whom Garraka froze to death. Ray suspects it is an apotropaic trap. After the group captures a ghost in Hell's Kitchen, Walter Peck, the Ghostbusters' long-time opponent, threatens to close them down with his authority as mayor. When the trio attempt to stop a ghost from stealing a phonographic recording of the club's ritual, Peck exploits Phoebe's involvement to shut down the Ghostbusters. To appease him, Callie removes underage Phoebe from the team. Phoebe attempts to control her emotions by playing chess in a nearby park, where she encounters and befriends Melody, the ghost of a teenage girl who died in a fire. She uses his extraction equipment to project herself as a ghost for two minutes so the pair can physically interact. Melody reveals she had been secretly working with Garraka, who has offered her passage to the afterlife. By controlling Phoebe's disembodied spirit, Garraka forces her physical body to recite the ritual chant. Realizing Garraka will free the ghosts in the containment unit, the Ghostbusters gather to defend their headquarters, aided by Nadeem, who dons the Firemaster brass armor kept by his grandmother and attempts to master his powers. Peter Venkman, brought in to help, discovers Nadeem has latent pyrokinetic powers. After an argument with Gary and her mother, Phoebe runs away and takes Melody to Winston's research center. Garraka was confined in the orb due to being vulnerable to copper alloys combined with fire and lacking his devil horns which augment his powers. He then escapes, locates his horns and begins freezing the city. Garraka overpowers them and breaches the containment unit. Phoebe reconfigures her proton pack with copper alloys to strengthen it; Melody, betrayed by Garraka, atones by helping Nadeem utilize his powers to weaken Garraka. Ray, with help from his fellow veteran Ghostbusters, entraps the god by improvising the ruptured containment unit as a giant trap. Melody reconciles with Phoebe before departing for the afterlife to reunite with her family. As the city thaws, the Ghostbusters are hailed as heroes, with Peck forced to support the team and reinstate Phoebe. In a mid-credits scene, a trucker gets out of his truck to buy something from a vending machine, while the Mini-Pufts steal his vehicle in his absence.

openai/o3-mini-2025-01-31: <PLOT_SUMMARY>Many generations after Caesar's death, apes have established numerous clans, while most humans have become feral-esque. Noa, a young chimpanzee from a falconry-practicing clan, prepares for a coming-of-age ceremony by collecting eagle eggs with his friends Anaya and Soona. On his journey, he is joined by Raka, an orangutan who tells Noa about Caesar's teachings. As Noa takes Soona to look through a telescope he found on his journey, Mae travels to a human settlement at a satellite base, which is kept quarantined from the outside world. The apes notice they are being followed by a human scavenger; Raka offers her food and a blanket, naming her Nova. Noa hurries home to find his village burning; the raider leader Sylva kills Noa’s father before dropping him from a high platform. Left for dead, Noa awakens, discovering that his clan has been abducted, and as he hides from his attackers, the apes follow his horse back to his clan. He then buries his father and sets out to rescue his clan. During his desperate quest, Noa and Mae are captured and taken to the apes’ settlement. Frustrated and seeking answers, Noa confronts Mae, demanding the truth in exchange for his help. Mae reveals her identity, explaining that the raiders took Noa’s clan to a beachfront settlement located outside an old human vault. She further discloses that a hidden entrance to the vault exists and that inside lies a mysterious “book” capable of restoring speech to humanity. Motivated by the chance to reclaim his kin and disrupt the tyranny around him, Noa agrees to help her enter the vault, hoping to destroy Proximus’ settlement and lead his clan back home. Soon, Noa reunites with his clan and is introduced to the apes’ self-proclaimed king, Proximus Caesar. However, Proximus warns Noa that, despite his intelligence, Mae is driven by her own agenda, and he reveals that he has enslaved other clans to force them to work on opening the vault so he can access the human technology locked inside. Adding insult to injury, Proximus tells Mae that she can leave only if she divulges where the other weapons are stored. That very night, Proximus invites Noa to dinner along with Mae and Trevathan—a human prisoner tasked with teaching him about the old human world—but when Trevathan catches wind of their plot and tries to warn Proximus, Mae coldly kills him. Later, as the group crosses a bridge on their way to the settlement, they are ambushed by Sylva, and soon after, when the trio encounters a group of feral humans, Sylva’s raiders suddenly attack. Noa finds himself pursued by Sylva, but he cunningly traps and drowns his relentless foe. In the ensuing chaos, a human scavenger following Noa inadvertently cracks his egg during a scuffle before fleeing, and while Noa searches for a replacement egg, he encounters a group of ape raiders armed with electric weapons. Determined to press on, the group enters the vault—a military bunker housing a stockpile of weapons and Mae’s “book,” which is, in reality, a deciphering key for a satellite. As tensions escalate, Lightning, one of Proximus’s apes, threatens to kill Soona, but Mae intervenes by killing him with a gun she found. With the situation deteriorating, Mae flees the settlement while the apes climb to higher ground through the bunker. In the ensuing fight, Raka saves Mae from drowning even as he is swept away by the rapids. Refusing to yield to Proximus’s oppressive ambitions, Mae triggers explosives that flood the bunker with apes. In a desperate bid to turn the tables, she then delivers the decipher key, enabling the humans to reactivate the satellites and successfully contact other humans worldwide. Amidst the turmoil, Noa and Raka rescue Nova, who, to their surprise, can speak. Though Noa escapes the bunker with his clan, Proximus mounts a renewed attack against him. In the midst of the conflict, Noa argues that if weapons and technology are reserved solely for humans, then nothing truly belongs to the apes—raising a fundamental question about whether the two species can ever coexist peacefully given Mae’s divisive agenda. Eventually, as Noa’s clan returns to rebuild their home, Mae arrives to bid farewell, concealing a gun behind her back yet never revealing or using it. In a final act of defiance, Noa, Mae, Soona, and Anaya secretly plant explosives around the levee that surrounds the settlement; Mae later explains that she destroyed the bunker to prevent the apes from accessing human-made weapons, insisting that such power should remain solely in human hands. In the aftermath, the apes discover old picture books depicting humans as the once-dominant species—with images of apes confined in zoo cages—while Noa leads his clan in summoning their eagles to attack Proximus, sending him careening off a cliff into the sea.

They are almost arrested and escape to the Den of Thieves, where they receive aid from the den's leader Han, who is also a close friend of Zhen. Ping open their new restaurant. After escaping for good, Zhen reunites with Po, but he refuses to back down from facing The Chameleon, so she, Ping and Li head back to the Den of Thieves to convince them to help them save Po. Master Shifu then tells Po that he must advance and become a spiritual leader, which means Po can no longer be the Dragon Warrior and must find a suitable successor to take his place. Putting his trust in Zhen, Po gives her the Staff of Wisdom, with which she bests The Chameleon. Confident with his choice, Po and the Furious Five help train Zhen to become the next Dragon Warrior. They battle, but when Zhen intervenes, The Chameleon turns into a Chimera of several kung fu masters. He nearly falls to his death, but is rescued by his fathers, who convince him that sometimes change can be good. As they battle The Chameleon's army of Komodo dragons, Po attempts to reason with The Chameleon to no avail, although she does give the staff back to him as she no longer needs it. While returning to the Valley of Peace, Po chooses Zhen as his successor, much to Shifu's annoyance. In the Valley of Peace, Po helps Li Shan and Mr. Zhen reveals that Tai Lung's return was masqueraded by a sorceress known as The Chameleon, who can shape-shift into any animal she wants as well as copying various kung fu techniques simply by touching them. Po almost manages to escape, but The Chameleon, taking the form of Zhen, fools him and throws him off a cliff. With Zhen's assistance, Po heads to Juniper City to take down The Chameleon, little knowing that his fathers, worried that Po is in over his head this time, are following them. After encountering a shifty tavern and fighting off the inhabitants, they soon arrive at Juniper City. Po is able to outsmart Zhen and send her to prison, but a group of mine workers tell him that Tai Lung has returned and destroyed an entire quarry. After the battle, she then shifts into a copycat of Po, fights him, and soon traps him in a cage. Using the staff, The Chameleon summons every deceased kung fu master and steals their techniques, including Lord Shen, General Kai, and the real Tai Lung. Po, who was only pretending to be trapped, defeats The Chameleon using the staff and returns all of the stolen kung fu to their owners, who show respect to Po and return to the Spirit Realm, with Tai Lung taking The Chameleon with him. It is then revealed that Zhen has been acting as a double agent for The Chameleon; her task was to acquire Po's Staff of Wisdom, which has the power to access the Spirit Realm. Po struggles to choose the right candidate as he does not want to lose his status as the Dragon Warrior, and he stumbles upon a fox bandit named Zhen trying to steal ancient weapons from the Jade Palace. From there, Po and Zhen head to The Chameleon's lair until Po is captured.

<PLOT_SUMMARY>
Master Shifu then tells Po that he must advance and become a spiritual leader, which means Po can no longer be the Dragon Warrior and must find a suitable successor to take his place. Po struggles to choose the right candidate as he does not want to lose his status as the Dragon Warrior, and he stumbles upon a fox bandit named Zhen trying to steal ancient weapons from the Jade Palace. Po is able to outsmart Zhen and send her to prison, but a group of mine workers tell him that Tai Lung has returned and destroyed an entire quarry.

While returning to the Valley of Peace, Po chooses Zhen as his successor, much to Shifu's annoyance. Confident with his choice, Po and the Furious Five help train Zhen to become the next Dragon Warrior. Zhen reveals that Tai Lung's return was masqueraded by a sorceress known as The Chameleon, who can shape-shift into any animal she wants as well as copying various kung fu techniques simply by touching them.

With Zhen's assistance, Po heads to Juniper City to take down The Chameleon, little knowing that his fathers, worried that Po is in over his head this time, are following them. After encountering a shifty tavern and fighting off the inhabitants, they soon arrive at Juniper City. From there, Po and Zhen head to The Chameleon's lair until Po is captured.

After the battle, she then shifts into a copycat of Po, fights him, and soon traps him in a cage. It is then revealed that Zhen has been acting as a double agent for The Chameleon; her task was to acquire Po's Staff of Wisdom, which has the power to access the Spirit Realm. Using the staff, The Chameleon summons every deceased kung fu master and steals their techniques, including Lord Shen, General Kai, and the real Tai Lung.

Po almost manages to escape, but The Chameleon, taking the form of Zhen, fools him and throws him off a cliff. He nearly falls to his death, but is rescued by his fathers, who convince him that sometimes change can be good.

They are almost arrested and escape to the Den of Thieves, where they receive aid from the den's leader Han, who is also a close friend of Zhen. After escaping for good, Zhen reunites with Po, but he refuses to back down from facing The Chameleon, so she, Ping and Li head back to the Den of Thieves to convince them to help them save Po.

In the Valley of Peace, Po helps Li Shan and Mr. Ping open their new restaurant. Putting his trust in Zhen, Po gives her the Staff of Wisdom, with which she bests The Chameleon. They battle, but when Zhen intervenes, The Chameleon turns into a Chimera of several kung fu masters.

As they battle The Chameleon's army of Komodo dragons, Po attempts to reason with The Chameleon to no avail, although she does give the staff back to him as she no longer needs it. Po, who was only pretending to be trapped, defeats The Chameleon using the staff and returns all of the stolen kung fu to their owners, who show respect to Po and return to the Spirit Realm, with Tai Lung taking The Chameleon with him.

question:
The following plot summary of a movie has had the sentences randomly reordered. Rewrite the plot summary with the sentences correctly ordered. Begin the plot summary with <PLOT_SUMMARY>.

The sentences are:

Mothra restores the protective barrier of the Iwi's home and the portals. A Monarch observation outpost stationed in Hollow Earth picks up an unidentified signal. On Earth's surface, Godzilla continues to maintain order between humanity and giant monsters, known as ‘Titans’ — killing Titan Scylla in Rome and resting in the Colosseum afterwards. Godzilla, Kong, and Mothra return to the Hollow Earth and engage Skar King and Shimo in battle. They find the Monarch outpost destroyed. After a brief initial confrontation, Kong convinces Suko to lead him to the tribe's lair, and the two slowly bond on their journey. Andrews and Jia, alongside Titan veterinarian Trapper and conspiracy podcaster Bernie Hayes, travel to Hollow Earth to locate the source of the signal. Hoping to lure Godzilla to Hollow Earth to assist him, Kong surfaces in Cairo and calls out to Godzilla. Despite Kong's attempts to communicate, Godzilla attacks him, and a brief fight ensues until Mothra intervenes. Inspecting some ruins, they surmise that the signal was a telepathic distress call sent by the Iwi. As the group follows the signal, they discover a temple that leads them to a subterranean section that houses a surviving Iwi tribe, who communicate telepathically with each other, living beneath portals to the surface. Ilene Andrews, to worry. Jia reunites with Andrews and alleviates her fears by choosing to stay with her adopted mother. While observing Jia socializing with the Iwi, Andrews voices her fears to Trapper that Jia may choose to stay with her people and that Andrews would have to accept it. When a sinkhole opens near his home, Kong discovers an uncharted realm where a tribe of his species has survived, including a juvenile named Suko. The prophecy also indicates that Jia would be the key to reawakening Mothra. Monarch believes Godzilla is strengthening himself for an oncoming threat. Skar King and Shimo manage to use one of the portals to escape to the surface, forcing Godzilla and Kong to chase them to Rio de Janeiro, and Shimo induces a second ice age at Skar King's command. After undoing Shimo's ice age with his atomic breath, Godzilla returns to rest in the Colosseum. The factions are evenly matched until Suko arrives with Kong's axe and destroys the crystal controlling Shimo. Meanwhile, Godzilla kills Tiamat and absorbs cosmic radiation from her lair, which turns his dorsal plates magenta. Three years after defeating Mechagodzilla, Kong has established his new territory in the Hollow Earth and searches for more of his kind. The tribe's tyrannical leader, Skar King, battles Kong with the aid of an ancient ice-powered Titan, Shimo, whom he controls with pain using a crystal. Inside a temple, Andrews uncovers hieroglyphics displaying the past and future: Skar King once attempted to conquer the surface world, forced Shimo to trigger an ice age, and waged war against Godzilla's species, but Godzilla defeated him by trapping him and his tribe deep within Hollow Earth. Also sensing the signal, Godzilla leaves Rome and attacks a nuclear plant in France to absorb radiation. Shimo's ice breath injures Kong's right arm, causing frostbite, but with Suko's help, Kong manages to escape after losing his axe. Shimo freezes Skar King before Kong shatters him to pieces. He then heads to the lair of the Titan Tiamat in the Arctic. Unknown to them, one of Skar King's loyalists follows them and informs him that the protective barrier leading to the surface portals has been opened. Sensing Jia, Kong locates the temple and is fitted by Trapper with a prototype exoskeletal glove to strengthen and heal his frostbitten limb. On the surface, the signal causes Jia, the last known survivor of the Iwi tribe from Skull Island, to experience hallucinations and visions, causing her adoptive mother and Kong expert, Dr. Kong returns with Shimo and Suko to Hollow Earth, where he becomes the ape tribe's new leader. Jia successfully awakens the reborn Mothra.

On Earth's surface, Godzilla continues to maintain order between humanity and giant monsters, known as ‘Titans’ — killing Titan Scylla in Rome and resting in the Colosseum afterwards. Also sensing the signal, Godzilla leaves Rome and attacks a nuclear plant in France to absorb radiation. He then heads to the lair of the Titan Tiamat in the Arctic. Monarch believes Godzilla is strengthening himself for an oncoming threat. When a sinkhole opens near his home, Kong discovers an uncharted realm where a tribe of his species has survived, including a juvenile named Suko. The tribe's tyrannical leader, Skar King, battles Kong with the aid of an ancient ice-powered Titan, Shimo, whom he controls with pain using a crystal. Shimo's ice breath injures Kong's right arm, causing frostbite, but with Suko's help, Kong manages to escape after losing his axe. Andrews and Jia, alongside Titan veterinarian Trapper and conspiracy podcaster Bernie Hayes, travel to Hollow Earth to locate the source of the signal. They find the Monarch outpost destroyed. As the group follows the signal, they discover a temple that leads them to a subterranean section that houses a surviving Iwi tribe, who communicate telepathically with each other, living beneath portals to the surface. The prophecy also indicates that Jia would be the key to reawakening Mothra. Meanwhile, Godzilla kills Tiamat and absorbs cosmic radiation from her lair, which turns his dorsal plates magenta. Hoping to lure Godzilla to Hollow Earth to assist him, Kong surfaces in Cairo and calls out to Godzilla. Despite Kong's attempts to communicate, Godzilla attacks him, and a brief fight ensues until Mothra intervenes. Godzilla, Kong, and Mothra return to the Hollow Earth and engage Skar King and Shimo in battle. Skar King and Shimo manage to use one of the portals to escape to the surface, forcing Godzilla and Kong to chase them to Rio de Janeiro, and Shimo induces a second ice age at Skar King's command. The factions are evenly matched until Suko arrives with Kong's axe and destroys the crystal controlling Shimo. Shimo freezes Skar King before Kong shatters him to pieces. After undoing Shimo's ice age with his atomic breath, Godzilla returns to rest in the Colosseum. Jia reunites with Andrews and alleviates her fears by choosing to stay with her adopted mother. Mothra restores the protective barrier of the Iwi's home and the portals. Kong returns with Shimo and Suko to Hollow Earth, where he becomes the ape tribe's new leader.

I'll reorder the sentences to create a coherent plot summary:

<PLOT_SUMMARY>
Three years after defeating Mechagodzilla, Kong has established his new territory in the Hollow Earth and searches for more of his kind. On Earth's surface, Godzilla continues to maintain order between humanity and giant monsters, known as 'Titans' — killing Titan Scylla in Rome and resting in the Colosseum afterwards. A Monarch observation outpost stationed in Hollow Earth picks up an unidentified signal. Also sensing the signal, Godzilla leaves Rome and attacks a nuclear plant in France to absorb radiation. He then heads to the lair of the Titan Tiamat in the Arctic. Meanwhile, Godzilla kills Tiamat and absorbs cosmic radiation from her lair, which turns his dorsal plates magenta. Monarch believes Godzilla is strengthening himself for an oncoming threat.

On the surface, the signal causes Jia, the last known survivor of the Iwi tribe from Skull Island, to experience hallucinations and visions, causing her adoptive mother and Kong expert, Dr. Ilene Andrews, to worry. Andrews and Jia, alongside Titan veterinarian Trapper and conspiracy podcaster Bernie Hayes, travel to Hollow Earth to locate the source of the signal. They find the Monarch outpost destroyed. Inspecting some ruins, they surmise that the signal was a telepathic distress call sent by the Iwi.

When a sinkhole opens near his home, Kong discovers an uncharted realm where a tribe of his species has survived, including a juvenile named Suko. After a brief initial confrontation, Kong convinces Suko to lead him to the tribe's lair, and the two slowly bond on their journey. The tribe's tyrannical leader, Skar King, battles Kong with the aid of an ancient ice-powered Titan, Shimo, whom he controls with pain using a crystal. Shimo's ice breath injures Kong's right arm, causing frostbite, but with Suko's help, Kong manages to escape after losing his axe.

As the group follows the signal, they discover a temple that leads them to a subterranean section that houses a surviving Iwi tribe, who communicate telepathically with each other, living beneath portals to the surface. Inside a temple, Andrews uncovers hieroglyphics displaying the past and future: Skar King once attempted to conquer the surface world, forced Shimo to trigger an ice age, and waged war against Godzilla's species, but Godzilla defeated him by trapping him and his tribe deep within Hollow Earth. The prophecy also indicates that Jia would be the key to reawakening Mothra. While observing Jia socializing with the Iwi, Andrews voices her fears to Trapper that Jia may choose to stay with her people and that Andrews would have to accept it.

Unknown to them, one of Skar King's loyalists follows them and informs him that the protective barrier leading to the surface portals has been opened. Sensing Jia, Kong locates the temple and is fitted by Trapper with a prototype exoskeletal glove to strengthen and heal his frostbitten limb. Jia successfully awakens the reborn Mothra. Jia reunites with Andrews and alleviates her fears by choosing to stay with her adopted mother.

Hoping to lure Godzilla to Hollow Earth to assist him, Kong surfaces in Cairo and calls out to Godzilla. Despite Kong's attempts to communicate, Godzilla attacks him, and a brief fight ensues until Mothra intervenes. Godzilla, Kong, and Mothra return to the Hollow Earth and engage Skar King and Shimo in battle. The factions are evenly matched until Suko arrives with Kong's axe and destroys the crystal controlling Shimo. Shimo freezes Skar King before Kong shatters him to pieces.

Skar King and Shimo manage to use one of the portals to escape to the surface, forcing Godzilla and Kong to chase them to Rio de Janeiro, and Shimo induces a second ice age at Skar King's command. After undoing Shimo's ice age with his atomic breath, Godzilla returns to rest in the Colosseum. Kong returns with Shimo and Suko to Hollow Earth, where he becomes the ape tribe's new leader. Mothra restores the protective barrier of the Iwi's home and the portals.
openai/o3-mini-2025-01-31: <PLOT_SUMMARY>Three years after defeating Mechagodzilla, Kong has established his new territory in the Hollow Earth and searches for more of his kind. On Earth's surface, Godzilla continues to maintain order between humanity and giant monsters, known as “Titans” — killing Titan Scylla in Rome and then resting in the Colosseum. A Monarch observation outpost stationed in Hollow Earth picks up an unidentified signal. Also sensing the signal, Godzilla leaves Rome and attacks a nuclear plant in France to absorb radiation. Monarch believes Godzilla is strengthening himself for an oncoming threat. Meanwhile, Ilene Andrews, Jia, Titan veterinarian Trapper, and conspiracy podcaster Bernie Hayes travel to Hollow Earth to locate the source of the mysterious signal. Inspecting some ruins, they surmise that the signal was a telepathic distress call sent by the Iwi. As the group follows the signal, they discover a temple that leads them into a subterranean section housing a surviving Iwi tribe that communicates telepathically beneath ancient portals to the surface. On the surface, the signal causes Jia—the last known survivor of the Iwi tribe from Skull Island—to experience vivid hallucinations and visions. Inside the temple, Andrews uncovers hieroglyphics displaying the past and future: Skar King once attempted to conquer the surface world, forced Shimo to trigger an ice age, and waged war against Godzilla’s species until Godzilla defeated him by trapping him and his tribe deep within Hollow Earth. The prophecy also indicates that Jia would be the key to reawakening Mothra. When a sinkhole opens near his home, Kong discovers an uncharted realm where a tribe of his own kind has survived, including a juvenile named Suko. After a brief initial confrontation, Kong convinces Suko to lead him to the tribe’s lair, and the two slowly bond on their journey. Hoping to lure Godzilla to Hollow Earth to assist him, Kong surfaces in Cairo and calls out to Godzilla. Despite Kong’s attempts to communicate, Godzilla attacks him, and a brief fight ensues until Mothra intervenes. Godzilla, Kong, and Mothra then return to the Hollow Earth and engage the tyrannical Skar King and his ancient, ice-powered Titan, Shimo, in battle. Upon their arrival, they find the Monarch observation outpost destroyed. The tribe’s ruthless leader, Skar King, battles Kong with the aid of Shimo—whom he controls by inflicting pain with a mystical crystal. Skar King and Shimo manage to use one of the portals to escape to the surface, forcing Godzilla and Kong to chase them all the way to Rio de Janeiro, while Shimo induces a second ice age at Skar King’s command. After undoing Shimo’s ice age with his atomic breath, Godzilla returns to rest in the Colosseum. During the ensuing conflict, Shimo’s ice breath injures Kong’s right arm, causing frostbite, but with Suko’s help, Kong manages to escape—even though he loses his axe in the process. The battle remains evenly matched until Suko arrives bearing Kong’s recovered axe and destroys the crystal controlling Shimo. Soon after, Shimo freezes Skar King before Kong shatters him to pieces. Then, Godzilla heads to the lair of the Titan Tiamat in the Arctic. There, he kills Tiamat and absorbs cosmic radiation from her lair, which turns his dorsal plates a striking magenta. Back among the Iwi, while observing Jia socializing with the tribe, Andrews voices her fears to Trapper that Jia may eventually choose to remain with her people. Reassuring her, Jia reunites with Andrews and alleviates her concerns by choosing to stay with her adoptive mother. In a moment of destiny, Jia successfully awakens the reborn Mothra. In response, Mothra restores the protective barrier of the Iwi’s home and the surrounding portals. Yet unknown to the heroes, one of Skar King’s loyalists follows events closely and informs his fallen master that the protective barrier leading to the surface portals has been opened. Meanwhile, the renowned Kong expert Dr. Kong returns with Suko to Hollow Earth, where he is recognized as the new leader of the ape tribe.

question:
The following plot summary of a movie has had the sentences randomly reordered. Rewrite the plot summary with the sentences correctly ordered. Begin the plot summary with <PLOT_SUMMARY>.

The sentences are:

Cassie returns to her apartment and finds Constance's notes, which reveal Ezekiel's identity and the true nature of his powers. Cassie uses her powers to guide the girls to safety. However, her clairvoyance enables her to see fully into the future. Cassie flies to Peru and tracks down the tribal chief who saved her mother. Ben's pregnant sister-in-law Mary goes into labor earlier than expected and he takes her to the hospital, along with the girls, who are seen on camera when in the car. Thirty years later, Cassandra, going by 'Cassie', works as a paramedic in New York City alongside her co-workers Ben Parker and O'Neil. Ben revives her, but she begins to experience visions. Initially, she dismisses them as déjà vu, but after failing to prevent O'Neil's death, Cassie realizes that she can see into the future. The group lures Ezekiel to a condemned firework factory and sets up traps to disorient him while Cassie calls for a medical evacuation helicopter to fly to their location. Cassie wakes up to discover that she is now blind and paraplegic due to her injuries. Ignoring Cassie's instructions, the girls go to a diner where Ezekiel finds them. Cassie is taken to the hospital just as Mary gives birth to her son. During a dangerous call, Cassie falls into the water and has a near-death experience. In 1973 in the jungles of Peru, a research team led by Ezekiel Sims and his pregnant colleague Constance Webb discovers an unidentified species of spider with rare healing properties. An indigenous tribe attempts to save Constance by having the spider bite her, but she dies shortly after giving birth to Cassandra. After briefly incapacitating Ezekiel by ramming him with the car, Cassie takes the girls back to Queens and they take refuge in Ben's house. Cassie assures the girls that she will mentor them in their future roles when the time comes. She steals a taxi and takes Julia, Anya, and Mattie out of the city to hide them in a nearby forest. Cassie is also drawn to the same girls and intervenes to stop Ezekiel from ambushing them at Grand Central Terminal. Ezekiel intercepts them again, but Cassie rescues the girls in an ambulance and distracts Ezekiel so Ben and Mary can escape. An ignited firework strikes Cassie in the face, blinding her. Ezekiel, who has limited precognition power and enhanced physical abilities, collects information on three teenage girls: Julia Cornwall, Anya Corazon, and Mattie Franklin. Ezekiel betrays the team and claims the spider for himself, shooting Constance in a struggle over the spider before leaving her for dead. She experiences a plane of higher consciousness where all living things are connected and where every possible future can be seen. ground_truth: In 1973 in the jungles of Peru, a research team led by Ezekiel Sims and his pregnant colleague Constance Webb discovers an unidentified species of spider with rare healing properties. Ezekiel betrays the team and claims the spider for himself, shooting Constance in a struggle over the spider before leaving her for dead. An indigenous tribe attempts to save Constance by having the spider bite her, but she dies shortly after giving birth to Cassandra. Thirty years later, Cassandra, going by 'Cassie', works as a paramedic in New York City alongside her co-workers Ben Parker and O'Neil. During a dangerous call, Cassie falls into the water and has a near-death experience. Ben revives her, but she begins to experience visions. Initially, she dismisses them as déjà vu, but after failing to prevent O'Neil's death, Cassie realizes that she can see into the future. Ezekiel, who has limited precognition power and enhanced physical abilities, collects information on three teenage girls: Julia Cornwall, Anya Corazon, and Mattie Franklin. His visions lead him to believe that they are destined to kill him. Cassie is also drawn to the same girls and intervenes to stop Ezekiel from ambushing them at Grand Central Terminal. She steals a taxi and takes Julia, Anya, and Mattie out of the city to hide them in a nearby forest. Cassie returns to her apartment and finds Constance's notes, which reveal Ezekiel's identity and the true nature of his powers. Ignoring Cassie's instructions, the girls go to a diner where Ezekiel finds them. After briefly incapacitating Ezekiel by ramming him with the car, Cassie takes the girls back to Queens and they take refuge in Ben's house. Cassie flies to Peru and tracks down the tribal chief who saved her mother. The chief puts Cassie through a ritual that separates her soul from her body. She experiences a plane of higher consciousness where all living things are connected and where every possible future can be seen. She learns that Constance sought the spider not for fame or money, as she had originally thought, but to save her from having the same fatal hereditary disease that Constance suffered from. Ben's pregnant sister-in-law Mary goes into labor earlier than expected and he takes her to the hospital, along with the girls, who are seen on camera when in the car. Ezekiel intercepts them again, but Cassie rescues the girls in an ambulance and distracts Ezekiel so Ben and Mary can escape. The group lures Ezekiel to a condemned firework factory and sets up traps to disorient him while Cassie calls for a medical evacuation helicopter to fly to their location. Ezekiel destroys the helicopter and separates the girls, then taunts Cassie with Constance's death. Cassie uses her powers to guide the girls to safety. She sets off the final trap, which fatally crushes Ezekiel. An ignited firework strikes Cassie in the face, blinding her. Cassie is taken to the hospital just as Mary gives birth to her son. Cassie wakes up to discover that she is now blind and paraplegic due to her injuries. However, her clairvoyance enables her to see fully into the future. Cassie assures the girls that she will mentor them in their future roles when the time comes.

openai/o3-mini-2025-01-31:
<PLOT_SUMMARY>In 2010, New York City photographer Jae Donnelly stakes out a private Manhattan home for an exclusive shot. Soon after, Jae calls to warn that Jeffrey Epstein is about to be taken into custody by the FBI for child sex trafficking, and he eventually captures a controversial image of Prince Andrew walking with Epstein in Central Park—snapping the shot immediately after photographing a young girl leaving the building. Nine years later, directly after major staffing cuts are announced at Newsnight, young guest producer Sam McAlister comes across that very photo, published alongside an article about a Prince Andrew–sponsored event for young entrepreneurs.

Spurred by this discovery, Sam informs programme editor Esme and rushes to the office of Prince Andrew’s private secretary, Amanda Thirsk, who has worked for the Duke for seven years. Amanda is convinced that the Epstein photo is the key reason the palace’s event was largely ignored by the press. Having spoken to Sam recently, Amanda agrees to negotiate terms for a Newsnight interview with the prince. In the morning, she calls Sam with the confirmed interview time, and the very next day, Amanda invites Sam to Buckingham Palace. There, Sam arranges a negotiation meeting that includes Amanda, Prince Andrew, and his daughter Beatrice.

After tea on the palace grounds, Sam convinces Amanda to step away for a drink. However, both Amanda and Sam face criticism over the informal meeting—PR representative Jason Stein and another journalist question the propriety of the drinks rendezvous. Later, when Esme, upset by Sam’s vocally critical comments about lead presenter Emily Maitlis and her apparently sensationalist leanings, pulls her aside, Sam vents her frustration at home. Arriving home, Sam finds her mother looking after her teenage son Lucas. Her mother gives her a much-needed pep talk, reminding her of the responsibility she bears for the groundbreaking story—a responsibility compounded by Sam’s challenges as a single mother who once worked in banking while serving Andrew for seven years. Even amid long working hours, Sam tries to maintain personal connections; she bonds with colleagues over shared interests, even jokingly buying takeout to celebrate a crush a co-worker has on someone.

As negotiations for the interview continue, Amanda inquires about Emily’s character and asks what Sam truly knows about her, hinting that despite the tension, the team must find a way to work together. Meanwhile, Jason is consulted about the unfolding crisis. Although the prince insists that he severed his friendship with Epstein following the exposure of Epstein’s original underage sex scandals—and even goes on to insist that Epstein had been involved “for many years”—Jason recommends that Amanda reach out to several ‘friendly’ reporters for one-on-one interviews in a bid to salvage Prince Andrew’s public image.

The fallout from the scandal comes into sharp focus during the televised interview broadcast on 16 November 2019, which centers on Prince Andrew’s relationship with convicted sex offender Epstein and allegations that he sexually assaulted a minor—claims he repeatedly denies. Nevertheless, in early 2022, despite his denials, Prince Andrew settles out of court for £12 million in Virginia Giuffre’s civil lawsuit over alleged sexual assault. Soon after, amid damning remarks—including bizarre, erratic statements about visiting a PizzaExpress in Woking and an apparent inability to sweat—that only deepen the public’s dismay, the Duke chooses to step down from his royal duties, marking a major PR crisis for the Royal Family.

In the midst of these revelations, Jae Donnelly gets back in touch with Sam, sharing additional photos of young girls moving in and out of Epstein’s Manhattan home—further fueling the controversy and complicating an already explosive situation.

So now, he basically made her go in circles to fall in love with him again. Guney already knew that Alin worked for Interpol, and he left a trail for her to find him on purpose. Faysal has a private painting collection. After 3 years, he did a press conference to show up on the grid again, but by this time, Alin had already started to work for Interpol in Paris. The thief seems to be breaking into museums and stealing the least valuable works of art, ignoring the other priceless artifacts in the same location. ground_truth: Alin (Esra Bilgic) and Ozan (Ushan Cakir) are Interpol officers who have been assigned to investigate a series of art thefts around the world. The thief seems to be breaking into museums and stealing the least valuable works of art, ignoring the other priceless artifacts in the same location. They quickly realize that the art thief is not grabbing the least valued paintings at the museums but specifically all paintings related to love. Putting this together helps them figure out the next target for the thief. Alin is right, but the thief is able to grab the painting in broad daylight with no one knowing and leave Alin just enough of a trace, see his face, but not be able to catch him. Alin immediately knows who the thief is now. Her ex-lover, Guney (Birkan Sokullu). Guney and Alin were going steady when he suddenly disappeared, without explanation, and left her heart broken. Interpol chief refuses to arrest Guney, as he is a billionaire and can easily buy the paintings he wants. He also says that Alin has a history with Guney, and hence they need solid evidence against him. Alin decides she's going to use her charm to catch Guney red-handed. When Alin approaches Guney, he asks her for a second chance, and she pretends to reluctantly give in. Guney explains that he ran away the first time as he was scared of commitment. In the meantime, Ozan has the information to figure out who is working with Guney now, and they also find a warehouse where they work. Alin tries to go there and get some evidence, but she's caught by Vera, Guney's hacker. Vera and Alin get into a physical fight, leading Vera to believe Alin is a cop. But she only manages to see her eyes as Alin was wise enough to cover her face. From the recovered material, Alin figures out that the next theft will be in Prague. Alin and Guney spend more time together, and he tells her that he doesn't want to spend time apart, but he has a business trip to Prague for two days. Alin convinces him to take her along. This is when she gets the billionaire treatment, and he takes her on a private jet and gifts her fancy new clothes. On the flight, Vera finds something strange about Alin and tells the other guy on their team, Omer (Hakan Ummak), that she might have been the cop who tried to break into the warehouse. At the time, Guney had dismissed the idea and said it must have been a random break-in. Alin's partner shows up at the hotel, saying she can't be doing a mission that her chief denied, but she's determined to catch Guney. However, Ozan thinks it's just her attraction to him that's keeping her there. Guney takes Alin to a private dress rehearsal for a romantic musical she's been wanting to watch, and it is enough for her to fall for Guney again. Alin and Guney almost go all the way in his hotel room, but Alin claims they're going too fast and leaves. The next day is the day of the robbery, and Guney leaves Alin with a car to use all day while he has some work. The second he's gone, Ozan and she follow him. Yet again, they're unable to catch him, and they're back to Istanbul and square one. Faysal Varli is an old man and a sleaze who is a businessman, and Guney plans on buying his company. Faysal has a private painting collection. He gives Alin and Guney a private viewing of this collection, and immediately, Alin realizes they're all stolen. This gives Guney the idea to break into the highly protected collection. This is a foolproof security system with too many layers, yet Guney has the confidence to break into it. There's a voice and face recognition step, and there are about 75 cameras leading up to the collection, so it's almost an impossible task. Additionally, there's a set of words, like a pass key, that keeps changing, that Faysal himself has to repeat for the vault to open. It's his voice that's recognized, but Guney has a solution for it all. Just as Guney is trying to break in and everything is going to plan, Faysal decides to bring a woman down to the vault. Vera freaks out, but just when they're about to enter the room, Faysal is asked to go back to the house. Alin is there to tell Faysal that his collection is going to be stolen from him, but he doesn't believe her. She tells him that she doesn't know who it will be, but she knows there's a plan. This is obviously not the answer he wants, so he chokes her to try and get her to spill, but Ozan shows up at that moment. He asks for the crime scene, but Faysal tells him to leave if he doesn't have a warrant. Alin decides the best thing to do is leave and take Ozan and the team with her. The next day, Faysal shows up in her bedroom, and finds out it was Guney who stole the painting thanks to her notes in her apartment with all the investigation on Guney. Alin tries to find Guney to warn him and tell him the truth. Guney already knew that Alin worked for Interpol, and he left a trail for her to find him on purpose. Guney had disappeared for some time without a trace because he was caught in Mexico. This left Alin heartbroken because he never reached out to her or told her anything about what he used to do. After 3 years, he did a press conference to show up on the grid again, but by this time, Alin had already started to work for Interpol in Paris. Apparently, he found it really hard to find her, and when he did, he couldn't just tell her he was a thief. So now, he basically made her go in circles to fall in love with him again. Guney takes Alin to his grandfather's house. It seems he got interested in art thanks to his grandfather, who was a wonderful painter but was never recognized for his work. However, the reason Guney decided to start stealing is because when they were first together, Alin told him that the Mona Lisa went up in value only after it got stolen. Faysal stands across from Guney and Alin in front of a lake, a dead end. Faysal shoots past Guney's ear, just missing him to threaten him. This is after Guney has been tormenting Alin to tell him she still loves him all the way while running away from Faysal. Just as Faysal is about to shoot again, Ozan shows up. Guney did Ozan a favor by giving him information about Faysal (when Guney broke into Faysal's vault, he found information and documents that linked Faysal to the drugs trade); in return, Ozan will leave Guney alone because he's only a harmless art and heart stealing person. Since Ozan is an ex-narcotics officer, he is, of course, thrilled to lock up Faysal. Alin promises not to turn Guney in and tells him she loves him. There are two options, one is that Alin stops working for Interpol so that she and Guney can go on a robbing spree since they won't really have anything else to do and they're both clearly so interested in art. On the other hand, Guney will stop stealing for the thrill of it and go back to being just a boring old billionaire. Or maybe they start an underground art gallery together with all the stolen pieces and never get found out.

openai/o3-mini-2025-01-31:
<PLOT_SUMMARY>Alin (Esra Bilgic) and Ozan (Ushan Cakir) are Interpol officers assigned to investigate a series of international art thefts. The case hits close to home when Alin’s past relationship is invoked—her ex-lover Guney (Birkan Sokullu) once was her boyfriend before he inexplicably vanished and left her heartbroken. Later, when Guney unexpectedly reappears—issuing a press conference after a three‐year hiatus—Alin, now working for Interpol in Paris, is drawn into a tangled web of passion and criminality. Guney had known all along about her job and deliberately left a trail for her to follow, a provocation rooted in the memory of a long-ago conversation when Alin confessed that the Mona Lisa only gained value after it was stolen.

As the investigation unfolds, recovered material leads Alin to deduce that the next art theft is scheduled to occur in Prague. Though she admits she doesn’t know who the criminal will be, she is convinced there is a meticulously orchestrated plan behind the string of robberies. Initially, the thief appears to be breaking into museums and targeting the least valuable works of art, deliberately ignoring priceless treasures. However, it soon becomes clear that the robberies are anything but random—each stolen painting is thematically connected to love.

Amid these clues, another player enters the picture: Faysal Varli, an old, sleazy businessman with a private collection of paintings. Guney, who now plans on buying Faysal’s company, conceives an audacious idea to break into Faysal’s highly protected vault. The vault is guarded by a state-of-the-art security system—it requires voice and face recognition, is monitored by roughly 75 cameras, and even relies on a constantly changing pass key that Faysal himself must recite for the vault to open. Although such layers would stump anyone else, Guney is confident he can pull it off.

Determined to thwart the robbery, Alin attempts to warn Faysal that his collection is in danger; however, he dismisses her concerns as mere paranoia. Meanwhile, Guney begins to woo Alin back into his world with grand gestures. He showers her with the billionaire treatment—taking her on a private jet ride with luxurious gifts and even treating her to a private dress rehearsal for a romantic musical, an experience that makes her fall for him all over again. Their intimacy escalates as they share a private viewing of Faysal’s collection—during which Alin instantly realizes that every piece on display has been stolen. Yet when a break-in is reported, Guney nonchalantly dismisses it as a random incident.

Complicating matters further is the dynamic between Alin’s lingering feelings and Ozan’s suspicions. When Guney later asks her for a second chance and she feigns reluctant acceptance, Ozan privately worries that her attraction to Guney is blinding her to the truth—making her effectively spin in circles as she falls in love with him again despite the risks. During a tense encounter, just as Faysal is about to fire again, Ozan—an ex-narcotics officer thrilled at the prospect of capturing a criminal—arrives on the scene and helps subdue the threat.

Guney’s intricate plan continues as he leaves subtle clues for Alin to follow. On one hand, he orchestrates the break-in with the precision of a seasoned thief; on the other, he apparently does Ozan a favor by providing incriminating details about Faysal—exposing links between the collector and the drugs trade—in return for leniency. In transit, while on a flight, Vera (Guney’s hacker) notices something unusual about Alin and confides in team member Omer (Hakan Ummak) that she suspects Alin may have once been a cop who tried breaking into a warehouse. Later, the team’s search leads them to a warehouse that appears to be a hub for Guney’s accomplices. At the hotel, Alin’s partner even shows up—defiant of her chief’s orders—and vows to catch Guney.

The tension builds to a climax during the heist. Guney, determined to infiltrate the seemingly impenetrable vault, finds his plan momentarily jeopardized when Faysal brings a mysterious woman down to the vault. Amid the ensuing chaos—Vera and Alin even engaging in a physical tussle that fuels suspicions about Alin’s true identity—the action spills into a final confrontation. Faysal corners Guney and Alin by a lakeside dead end, firing a shot that narrowly misses Guney’s ear as a menacing threat. Soon after, evidence gathered from Alin’s meticulously kept notes in her apartment confirms that it was indeed Guney who masterminded the theft.

In the aftermath, Guney explains that he had run away the first time because he was scared of commitment, and now he weighs the possibility of returning to a mundane billionaire life, giving up his thrill-seeking thefts. Torn between duty and lingering desire, Alin is forced to make an excruciating choice: should she abandon her career at Interpol to join Guney on a life of romantic, high-stakes art theft—or should she stay loyal to the law and pursue him with Ozan when he inevitably vanishes again? In a bittersweet epilogue, she even entertains the wild alternate vision of launching an underground art gallery featuring all the stolen masterpieces—a daring dream that, like the case itself, blurs the line between love and crime.

question:
The following plot summary of a movie has had the sentences randomly reordered. Rewrite the plot summary with the sentences correctly ordered. Begin the plot summary with <PLOT_SUMMARY>.

The sentences are:

In the aftermath, the village mourns the dead, and Kora admits her past, which Titus reveals he already knew. In the ensuing melee, while firing at the advancing crowd, Gi-su accidentally damages the suitcase—tragically killing So-yeon. Surrounded by an enraged mob poised to exact their revenge, Gi-su finds himself with nowhere to run. In the end, Nam-san takes matters into his own hands by killing Gi-su, and he returns to his village accompanied by Su-na and Ji-wan.

The crew takes their position on the A-380 on the day the gold is being transferred, but Luke pulls out of the heist at the last minute. Weeks later, Cyrus reveals to Abby that the crew stole the gold shipment during the heist on the airliner, replacing the actual shipment with iron bars painted to look like gold. Interpol agent Abby Gladwell (Gugu Mbatha-Raw), a former fling of Cyrus, uncovers evidence implicating Denton, in the theft and arrests him. The crew determines they will only be able to steal the gold while the airliner is in mid-air. Luke was never out; he guided the parachute to a recoverable spot in the mountains via remote control. As Leviathan requires payment of $500 million in untraceable gold bullion, Jorgenson has arranged for a shipment of gold to be taken from his vault in London and flown to Leviathan's bank in Zurich via a commercial airliner. Huxley wants Cyrus and his crew to intercept this gold payment to Leviathan. Huxley cannot intercept the gold as it is a legal transaction. N8 decides to celebrate with the team after being promised a cut of the money ($27 million). Harry then calls the A-380 pilots and diverts them to Cortina due to heavy weather in Zurich. Cyrus and his team successfully divert the plane. After Magnus cracks the safe and Jorgenson's henchmen are incapacitated, the crew will extract the gold from the A-380 once it lands in the Swiss Alps. This mask will create the NFT, with a live 30-second feed from the auction itself.
